newsitem.title: GERMANY: German region to continue observing Scientology.
newsitem.headline: German region to continue observing Scientology.

text.p: The southern German state of Baden-Wuerttemberg said on Tuesday a university expert opinion on the Church of Scientology had strengthened its resolve to keep the organisation under observation.
"A study by the University of Tuebingen has strengthened my opinion that Scientology's programme is a threat to a state ruled by law," state interior minister Thomas Schaeuble said in a statement.
The study, based only on readily available documents, found no evidence that Scientology should be categorised as a criminal organisation, and no proof of involvement in organised or economic crime.

It said a number of source materials backed the hypothesis that Scientology, based on the teachings of late American science fiction author L. Ron Hubbard, was capable of exerting "extreme pressure" on people and fostering unusual dependency.

But it said it had not been possible to prove that contact with the organisation had long-term psychological consequences or encouraged people to commit suicide. It recommended further investigations.

Baden-Wuerttemberg and the neighbouring state of Bavaria are at the forefront of efforts in Germany to maintain checks on Scientology, and both have the organisation observed by their anti-extremist watchdogs.
Scientology's German branch attacked Schaeuble's comments.

It said in a statement that he had chosen to ignore the fact that the report "clearly refutes" allegations made against the organisation, and was instead mounting a "hysterical witchhunt" against Scientology at taxpayers' expense.

German authorities consider Scientology to be a profit-making organisation, not a religion. Officials say it exploits the insecurities of members to make money from expensive self-improvement courses.

This year's annual human rights report from the U.S. State Department listed Scientology's allegations of persecution in Germany, and the issue has prompted protests from U.S. entertainment celebrities.
